item.title: When 0.1 + 0.2 Does Not Equal 0.3
item.description: One of the workshops I occasionally give in the IMHR is a review of basic computer-programming principles. I’d say the programming experience for the majority of our psychology students is acquired in a pretty haphazard, piecemeal fashion—usually by learning whatever R they need to know to make it through their statistics coursework and complete their research projects.1 So they invariably end up missing some critical “bits” (pardon the pun) of knowledge.

item.title: Everything You Know about the P-Value is Wrong
item.description: I know, yet another post tut-tutting the misuse of p-values. But there are still a lot of folks who are not woke to the problem. Last year, a good friend who is an investigational pharamcist asked for my help in putting together a session on the topic for the 2018 Hospital Pharamcy Practice Seminar, which resulted in an invitation to write a guest article for the fantastic tl;dr pharmacy blog. So, if you want to read my version of the p-value sermon, check out this link to their website:

About this Blog Welcome to my GitHub pages! Here you will find links to R coding tips, tutorials, and in-depth walk-throughs of the data science I am using in my current research collaborations. I hope this will be useful to others in at least two respects: For those interested in reproducing research that has been published, you will find the exact code that I used in my data analysis.
